top_categories.workout_context: 67ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
Rooted Vermont's Vermont mountains, Rolling to mountainous gravel forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 75 miles.
At Rooted Vermont, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Rooted Vermont's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before race day.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Rooted Vermont. Train it until it feels boring.
75 miles on Vermont rolling to mountainous gravel burns energy faster than the distance suggests. Train the fade resistance now.
5,000ft of climbing on grades that change every minute. You need to switch from seated to standing without losing rhythm.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Rooted Vermont, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
5,000ft of climbing means repeated surges above threshold. VO2max work is how you survive the fifth climb, not just the first.
Double-threshold training builds sustained power with less fatigue. More FTP per hour of training.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on Vermont rolling to mountainous gravel. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for Rooted Vermont’s 75 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
